titlestmt.titleproper: Eddie Cochran Historical Organization Collection ARC.0005
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Somerville, Project Archivist

address.addressline: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-06-24T13:29-0400

did.abstract: The Eddie Cochran Historical Organization spans the years 1950-1993. The collection provides rich documentation of Eddie Cochran’s career, focusing on his vast impact on early rock and rockabilly music. Other artists included in the collection are Gene Vincent and Sharon Sheeley. The documents also provide insight into the workings of the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization, showcasing Cochran’s impact on individuals. The collection provides a unique look into the enthusiastic lengths music fans will go to in order to locate information about their idols and to preserve and honor their legacies. The collection is comprised of the administrative files of the historical organization; graphic materials depicting images of Cochran, including photographs, posters, and postcards; printed materials featuring information about Cochran, including newspapers, books, booklets, periodicals, clippings, and sheet music; and audiovisual materials featuring recordings by Cochran, in the form of videotapes, 45 RPM records, LP records, and mini-discs.

bioghist.head: Biography and Historical Note

chronitem.event: Began his musical career in California
Cut first record and signed with Liberty Records
Recorded his biggest hits “Summertime Blues” and “C’mon Everybody”
Died in a traffic accident in Somerset (England)
Inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame

bioghist.p: Though Eddie Cochran was only twenty-one when he died, he left his mark as a rock and roll pioneer. He epitomized the sound and style of the Fifties rebel rocker and was an innovative and highly influential guitarist. He was also proficient on piano, bass and drums. His short career, spanning only 6 years, produced many hit singles including “Summertime Blues,” “C’mon Everybody,” “Twenty Flight Rock,” “Something Else,” and “Nervous Breakdown.” These singles inspired many major artists; the first song Paul McCartney and John Lennon ever played together was “Twenty Flight Rock.” Other artists that have covered his songs include The Who, the Sex Pistols, Jimi Hendrix and The Clash.

Eddie Cochran only released one album during his lifetime, which was tragically cut short when he was killed in a traffic accident while riding in a taxi on his way to a London airport at the end of a British tour. Artist Gene Vincent and songwriter Sharon Sheeley, who was Cochran’s fiancé, were also injured in the accident. In his death, Cochran achieved iconic status with many generations of rock and rollers and his legacy and influence can still be seen today.

chronlist.head: Historical Note: Bruce C. Blake and the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization

chronitem.event: Incorporated as a Minnesota non-profit organization
Held first annual Eddie Cochran weekend in Alberta Lea, Minn.

bioghist.p: Bruce C. Blake founded the Eddie Cochran Collection in 1990 in Cochran’s hometown of Alberta Lea, Minnesota. A bill collector by trade, Blake was 26 years old when he formed the organization with the objective of honoring Eddie Cochran and promoting his music in the Alberta Lea area. Most local people were unaware that Cochran was from Alberta Lea before this organization was formed. Cochran’s family has since moved and he normally stated he was from Oklahoma (where his parents were from) to improve his country music credibility. The idea for the organization’s name, ECHO, was based on the name, EKKO, an early recoding label on which Cochran appeared. The original members of the organization included local individuals, several of which grew up in the area Cochran lived, those who liked early rock and roll music, and those acquainted with Cochran and believed it should be a source of pride for the community. The organization achieved its goals and created a strong memory of Cochran in his hometown and preserving his legacy for future generation. The organization disbanded in the late 1990s.
For further information on Bruce Blake and the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization, contact the Freeborn County Historical Museum.

list.head: Sources
list.item: Bream, Jon. “Hometown, Home State Finally Pay Tribute to Eddie Cochran.” Minneapolis-St. Paul Star Tribune. June 13, 1991.
Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum. “Eddie Cochran Biography.” http://rockhall.com/inductees.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Bruce C. Blake Collection of the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization, Library and Archives, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Bruce C. Blake Collection of the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization was received by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame Foundation, Inc. as two gifts from Bruce C. Blake: the first on June 21, 1993 and, the second, June 21, 1994.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum, Inc. owns right, title, and interest in the works of authorship embodied in the materials in this collection. The transfer of Donor's literary and other property rights does not include writings of other individuals and organizations contained in the gift. For more information, please consult the staff of the Library and Archives.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Patrons must sign the Acknowledgment of Legal Responsibility and Privacy Rights form before using this collection. Please contact reference staff before visiting the Library and Archives to use this collection.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Rachel Somerville. Completed May 30, 2010. Descriptive sources and standards used to create this inventory: DACS and local Style Guide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains files and documents dealing with the administrative aspects of the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization as well as the original Eddie Cochran Fan Club. Some documents include correspondence, newsletters, membership information and business cards. This series is arranged by type and then chronologically within the groupings.

did.unittitle: Original correspondence between fan club president and a member
Various correspondences from Tony Freer looking for information about Cochran
Fan letters written to Cochran, copies and originals (14 letters)
Original fan club lists of members
Fan club stationary and envelopes (3 copies of each)
Original sheets “To Start a Fan Club” from Cochran fan club
Original page from DIG magazine with article “How to form a Fan Club”
½ sheets sent out to those wishing to start a fan club (3 copies)
List of Eddie Cochran’s favorite things
Original “Price List” of materials from fan club
Fan club membership cards in pink, green, yellow, blue and white (3 copies of each)
Original Eddie Cochran business cards with Liberty Records (2 cards)
SGT. Jan S. Olson business cards (7 copies)
Original copies of the Eddie Cochran Fan Club newsletter, volume two,
Gene Vincent and Eddie Cochran International Fan Club magazine, GIT IT, issues 1 through 8
Cochran Connection Newsletter, volume 1, issue 2 (3 copies)
Cochran Connection Newsletter, volume 1, issue 3 (3 copies)
Cochran Connection Newsletter, volume 2, issue 1 (3 copies)
“Summertime Blues” Spanish fan club newsletter, volumes 1 through 8
Papers from the Eddie Cochran Memorial Society
Clipping from the Eddie Cochran Memorial Fund
Color photocopy of watercolor of Cochran done by a French fan
“The Girl Can’t Help It” promotional picture
Interview transcript, Dick D’Agostin and the Swingers (2 copies)
Maps and information about area Cochran died
Original calendar from New Musical Express

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Divided into 3 subseries: photographic materials, postcards and posters. Each subseries contain graphic materials featuring images of Eddie Cochran. The subseries are arranged by size and then chronologically within each grouping.

8x10 color photographs of Cochran from “The Girl Can’t Help It” (2 photographs)

8x10 photograph of Cochran with his confirmation class

8x10 photograph of Cochran from “Go, Johnny, Go”
8x10 photographs of Cochran taken on his 21st birthday (6 photographs)

8x10 photograph of Cochran and Sharon Sheeley in 4 different poses
8x10 promotional photograph of Cochran, facial close-ups (13 copies)
8x10 photograph of Cochran looking over his shoulder (27 copies)
8x10 photograph of Cochran, in jacket, with hands resting on back of chair (25 copies)
8x10 promotional photograph of Cochran with the Flamingos
8x10 photographs of the Cochran Brothers, (2 photographs)
8x10 photograph of Cochran with Gene Vincent
8x10 photograph of Cochran playing for 5 people

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Divided into 6 subseries: newspapers, books, booklets, periodicals, clippings and sheet music. Each subseries contain materials relating to Eddie Cochran’s life, career, death and legacy. The files are arranged alphabetically by title and/or author and then chronologically.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Books have been transfered to the library collection. Please search for "Bruce C. Blake Collection of the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization" in the library catalog for a list of donated titles.

did.unittitle: Album of Hillbilly and Western Favorites souvenir booklet
Biggest Show of the Stars for ‘57 tour booklet
Country and Western Caravan on Tour souvenir booklet
Something Else: A Tribute to Eddie Cochran booklet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Divided into 4 subseries: videotapes, 45 RPM records, LP records and mini-discs. Each subseries contain materials recorded by or relating to Eddie Cochran. The items are arranged alphabetically within each subseries.

did.unittitle: Bobby Cochran and the Rhythm Rockers
Bobby Cochran and the Rock Around the Clock Show

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: 45 RPM records have been transfered to the library collection. Please search for "Bruce C. Blake Collection of the Eddie Cochran Historical Organization" in the library catalog for a list of donated titles.
